title: Appendicitis Inflammatory Response (AIR) Score
description: Diagnoses appendicitis based on clinical and laboratory findings using objective inflammatory variables and clinical signs of peritoneal irritation

parameters.name: rebound_tenderness
parameters.description: Rebound tenderness (percussion tenderness reflecting peritoneal irritation)

ranges.interpretation: Outpatient follow-up if unaltered general condition. Consider other diagnoses. Can be discharged with planned reexamination if clinically stable.
Admit patient for observation and serial reassessment. Consider rescoring after 4-8 hours of observation. May require imaging studies or surgical consultation.
High suspicion for appendicitis. Surgical consultation recommended. Consider immediate surgical intervention, especially in patients with advanced appendicitis.

references: Andersson M, Andersson RE. The appendicitis inflammatory response score: a tool for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis that outperforms the Alvarado score. World J Surg. 2008;32(8):1843-9.
Sammalkorpi HE, Mentula P, Leppäniemi A. A new adult appendicitis score improves diagnostic accuracy of acute appendicitis—a prospective study. BMC Gastroenterol. 2014;14:114.

Scott AJ, Mason SE, Arunakirinathan M, et al. Risk stratification by the Appendicitis Inflammatory Response score to guide decision-making in patients with suspected appendicitis. Br J Surg. 2015;102(5):563-72.
formula: AIR Score = Vomiting (0-1) + RIF pain (0-1) + Rebound tenderness (0-3) + Fever ≥38.5°C (0-1) + Polymorphonuclear % (0-2) + WBC count (0-2) + CRP level (0-2)
notes: The AIR Score is designed to have high sensitivity for advanced appendicitis, which is most clinically important to identify
Patients with short duration of symptoms may have low scores as their immune system has not yet reacted fully
Consider rescoring after a few hours in patients with short symptom duration
The score works especially well in children and women, but may be less specific in elderly patients
Advanced appendicitis often has lymphopenia, so normal or low WBC with high neutrophil percentage is significant
The proportion of neutrophils is particularly important as it reflects the inflammatory response
Rebound tenderness reflects peritoneal irritation and is a key clinical finding
External validation shows good performance across age groups 2-96 years
